weekly_desc:
This week felt like a bit of a blur, honestly. It’s strange looking back because while I was definitely *around* campus, it feels like I didn't quite hit my stride academically.

My class schedule is pretty consistent, but the system says I had "no class experience" this week, and I can see why. I was in the Life Sciences Center on Wednesday and Friday, which aligns with COSC 060, but it didn't feel like I was fully engaged, or maybe I just wasn't in the right room at the right time for the system to pick it up. And Thursday and Monday were definitely a miss for both COSC 060 and COSC 065. I was in my dorm during those times, or even at Sudikoff for a bit on Thursday, which isn't where COSC 060 is. It's a bit concerning, especially with all these deadlines piling up. There are so many things due on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday next week, and I really need to get on top of them. My knowledge level feels pretty average right now, and I know I need to boost that.

Outside of classes, I spent a lot of time in Parker House, just chilling or doing my own thing. It's comfortable, but maybe a little too comfortable sometimes. I did make it to the Boathouse quite a few times, which is always good. I enjoy being out on the water, and it's a great way to clear my head and keep my stamina up. I also hit the gym a couple of times, which felt good. It's nice to have those outlets to stay active. I even popped into Goldstein Hall and the Hopkins Center, and saw the Sphinx building, which was interesting. Just exploring a bit, I guess.

Socially, things were pretty low-key. My extraversion isn't super high, so I'm fine with my own company, but I do appreciate connecting with people. I didn't really have any big social outings this week. My social meter is at 50, which feels about right. I'm not feeling isolated, but I also haven't gone out of my way to organize anything.

The biggest challenge is definitely getting back on track with my coursework. Missing classes isn't ideal, and now with all these deadlines looming, I can feel the pressure building. My sleep and stamina are both at 100, which is great, so I have the physical energy, it's just about channeling it effectively. My happiness is at 50, which is okay, but I think getting a handle on my academics would definitely boost that.

For next week, my main goals are clear:
1.  **Attend every single class.** No excuses. I need to be present and engaged in COSC 060 and COSC 065.
2.  **Tackle those deadlines head-on.** I'm going to map out all the assignments due on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday and make a plan to get them done. I need to be more conscientious about my work.
3.  **Utilize campus resources.** Maybe spend more time studying in the library or Sudikoff, rather than just my dorm, to help me focus.
4.  **Keep up with physical activity.** The Boathouse and gym sessions are good for me, and I want to maintain that balance.

I'm feeling ready to turn things around and make next week a much more productive one.
judge_reasoning:
```

weekly_desc:
Okay, another week done. It feels like it flew by, honestly.

Looking back, I definitely didn't make it to any of my scheduled COSC classes this week. The system even flagged it as "no class experience," which is pretty accurate. I know COSC 060 and 065 meet regularly, and I should have been there, especially with all the deadlines piling up. It's not ideal, and I feel a bit of a pang of responsibility about it, knowing how much work is coming.

My schedule was a bit all over the place. I spent a lot of time in Parker House, just kind of doing my own thing. There were a few late nights, like Wednesday when I was up until 1 AM, and then again on Saturday and Sunday, and even Monday and Tuesday early mornings. It's weird because despite the late hours, I still feel pretty well-rested and have good stamina, which is a plus, I guess. Maybe it's just my body adjusting to a different rhythm.

I did manage to get out to a few academic buildings, even if it wasn't for class. I was at Sudikoff Hall late Wednesday, and then Vail and Fairchild on Friday. I think I was trying to get some work done on my own, which is good, but it's not the same as being in lecture. I also made it to the Sphinx Secret Society on Monday evening, which was a nice break and good to connect with people there. Other times, I was just... around, or in unknown spots, which is kind of how it goes sometimes.

Overall, my happiness level feels pretty neutral, which is fine. I'm not overly stressed, even with the missed classes and the mountain of deadlines coming up. Seriously, there are so many things due on Monday and Wednesday next week. That's the big challenge staring me down.

So, for next week, my main goal is to get back on track with classes. I really need to make it to COSC 060 and 065. And, obviously, I need to buckle down and tackle these deadlines. It's a lot, but I'm confident I can get through it if I manage my time better. I'll try to be more intentional about my academic time and make sure I'm where I need to be.

My knowledge levels are definitely reflecting that, which is a bit of a wake-up call. It's not ideal, and I know I need to address it.

It's always interesting there, and I like feeling involved, even if it means I'm not always in the classroom. I even managed to catch something at the Hopkins Center for the Arts on Monday, which was a nice break.

Socially, things felt pretty good. I wasn't constantly out, but the activities I was doing felt meaningful, and I enjoyed the interactions. My sleep has been solid, which is always a win, and I feel pretty well-rested.

The biggest challenge staring me down right now is the sheer number of deadlines coming up, especially on Monday and Tuesday. It's a lot, and given that I haven't been as on top of my classes as I should be, I'm feeling the pressure to catch up quickly. It's a bit daunting, but I know I can tackle it.

For next week, my main goal is to get back on track with my academics. I absolutely need to prioritize attending COSC 060 and 065. I've got to make up for lost time and really dive into those assignments. I'll still make time for the Boathouse and other activities because they're important for my well-being, but the balance needs to shift heavily towards my coursework. I'm feeling good physically and mentally, so it's just about channeling that energy into the right places. Time to buckle down.

Academically, this week was... different. I noticed the system didn't record any class experience, and that's pretty accurate. I didn't make it to my COSC 060 or COSC 065 lectures this week. It wasn't ideal, and I usually try to be really on top of attendance, but with so many deadlines looming, I made the call to prioritize getting some major project work done. There are so many assignments due on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, and I felt like I needed to dedicate solid, uninterrupted blocks of time to them. That's why I spent a lot of time in Sudikoff Hall, especially late at night. I was there on Wednesday, Sunday, and Monday, just grinding away. It's a good space to focus. I even found myself in Fairchild Physical Sciences Center super late on Monday and Tuesday nights, which was a change of scenery but still all about getting work done. It's a bit of a weird schedule, being up so late, but I seem to be catching up on sleep fine, so it works for now.

Outside of the academic grind, I did manage to get out a little. I popped over to the Hood Museum on Wednesday evening, which was a nice break from screens and code. Looking ahead to next week, my main goal is to get back on track with my classes. I need to catch up on the lectures I missed, probably by watching recordings, and make sure I understand everything before the next set of topics. I also want to try and get a head start on any new assignments so I don't end up in the same crunch again. They do plan to "Re-evaluate class attendance," suggesting a slight awareness of potential gaps, but currently feel competent.
- **Stress:** The student directly states, "I'm not feeling too stressed about it, which is good," despite acknowledging "a mountain of deadlines." They express an overall positive outlook, saying, "Overall, I'm feeling positive" and "I'm getting things done, and I'm feeling good while doing it."
- **Happy:** The student repeatedly expresses positive emotions, stating, "This week felt pretty good, actually," "I'm still feeling really happy," "I really enjoy being out there [Boathouse]," and "Overall, I'm feeling positive."
- **Sleep:** The student explicitly mentions, "I'm still feeling really happy and well-rested." Although they also note "a lot of late nights and early mornings," their self-assessment of being "well-rested" indicates a high perceived quality of sleep or recovery.
- **Social:** The student clearly states, "My social life was pretty quiet again this week," and "My social score is still super low, but honestly, I'm okay with that." They prefer "focusing on my own things" and only consider "a tiny social step" for next week, confirming low social engagement and satisfaction with it.

weekly_desc:
This week felt like a bit of a blur, honestly. It's funny, despite the constant grind, I feel pretty good – my happiness, sleep, and stamina are all surprisingly high. I guess that consistent time at the boathouse really helps keep me grounded and energized. Those early morning and late-night sessions out on the water are definitely my escape.

Academically, it was a heavy week, especially with all those deadlines piling up for Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. I spent *a lot* of time in Sudikoff Hall, practically living there some nights. I was definitely pulling some late ones, like that all-nighter into Wednesday morning, just trying to get everything done. It feels good to dive deep into the material when I'm working on projects, and I think my knowledge is building up, even if it's not always from the traditional classroom setting.

Speaking of which, I didn't make it to any of my scheduled classes this week. I know, I know. It's not ideal. With so many project deadlines looming, I found myself prioritizing the hands-on work and self-study in Sudikoff over attending lectures. It felt like I had to make a choice, and getting those assignments done was the immediate priority. I was mostly in my dorm during class times, trying to focus or just catch a breath before heading back to the CS building. It's a bit of a balancing act, and sometimes I feel like I'm just trying to keep my head above water with the workload.

My social life, well, that's still pretty much non-existent. My social score is super low, and looking back at the week, I can see why. I was either in my dorm, at the boathouse, or holed up in Sudikoff. I didn't really connect with anyone outside of those spaces, and even then, it was mostly just passing by. I'm not the most outgoing person anyway, so it doesn't feel like a huge void, but sometimes I do wonder if I should try to branch out a little more. That random trip to the West Lebanon Post Office was probably the most "out there" thing I did all week, which is kind of sad when I think about it.

The biggest challenge was definitely managing the sheer volume of work and those back-to-back deadlines. It felt like a constant race against the clock, and I ended up sacrificing class time to get the projects done.

For next week, my main goal is to get back into a better rhythm with classes. I really need to make an effort to attend COSC 060 and 065. I also want to try and get a head start on assignments so I'm not pulling so many all-nighters right before deadlines. It would be nice to maintain my boathouse routine, as that's clearly helping me stay sane and energized. And maybe, just maybe, I'll try to grab a meal with someone or just have a quick chat with a classmate. Small steps, right?
judge_reasoning:
```

Reasoning:
- **Stamina**: The student explicitly states "my happiness, sleep, and stamina are all surprisingly high" and mentions the "consistent time at the boathouse really helps keep me grounded and energized." While they pulled an "all-nighter," their overall feeling is one of high energy and resilience.
- **Knowledge**: The student feels their "knowledge is building up" as they "dive deep into the material when I'm working on projects" and prioritize "hands-on work and self-study."
- **Stress**: The student describes a "heavy week, especially with all those deadlines piling up," pulling "all-nighter[s]," and feeling like they're "just trying to keep my head above water with the workload" and that it was a "constant race against the clock."
- **Happy**: The student directly states, "I feel pretty good – my happiness, sleep, and stamina are all surprisingly high," and finds joy and escape in "consistent time at the boathouse."
- **Sleep**: The student claims "my happiness, sleep, and stamina are all surprisingly high." However, they also mention "pulling some late ones, like that all-nighter into Wednesday morning," which would significantly impact sleep quality and quantity for the week, thus tempering the "high" assessment.
- **Social**: The student repeatedly states, "My social life, well, that's still pretty much non-existent" and "My social score is super low," explaining they were "holed up in Sudikoff" and "didn't really connect with anyone."

project.full_text_response:
This is an exceptionally well-articulated and thoughtfully scoped project idea. You've clearly identified a genuine pain point for university students and proposed a practical, relevant solution.

Here's my evaluation based on the criteria:

*   **Is the idea innovative or unique compared to existing apps?**
    While campus maps exist, the focus on dynamic availability (even if simulated for the project) and granular amenity-based filtering for study spaces is a significant step beyond static information. It addresses a specific, nuanced need that isn't typically met by general campus navigation tools. The "right environment" focus is a good differentiator.
*   **Does it clearly address a real problem or user need?**
    Absolutely. The frustration of finding suitable study spots, especially with specific requirements (quiet, group, software), is a universal student experience. You've articulated this problem very well, demonstrating empathy for the user.
*   **Is the idea technically feasible for implementation by a student team within one semester?**
    Excellent consideration of feasibility. Your plan to simulate availability is a smart way to tackle a complex real-world feature within the constraints of a semester project, allowing you to demonstrate the *concept* without getting bogged down in real-time sensor integration. The listed programming concepts are appropriate and achievable.
*   **Is the scope appropriate (not too simple, not too ambitious)?**
    This is a perfect scope. It's far more complex and useful than a basic app, requiring multiple core mobile development skills (UI/UX, data persistence, navigation, filtering, potentially API integration, notifications). Yet, by carefully defining the "simulated" aspects and focusing on core functionality, you've avoided over-ambition. The Pomodoro timer and favorites add value without bloat.
*   **Does it demonstrate thoughtful consideration of user experience and impact?**
    Yes, very much so. Your emphasis on "optimizing a student's time and reducing stress," "clean, intuitive interface," and the detailed filtering options all point to a strong user-centric design approach. You're not just building an app; you're solving a problem for a specific user group.

This project demonstrates a strong understanding of both the problem domain and the technical requirements of mobile application development. You've clearly put significant thought into balancing innovation with feasibility.

**29/30**
